            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>During the summer of 2014, the southern Northwest Territories (NWT) experienced an unprecedented fire season, with a burn fingerprint that spread across two ecoregions (the Taiga Plains and Taiga Shield), and a landscape that is underlain by mosaic of permafrost coverage, vegetation type, and previous fire history.  Our study was conducted across the Dehcho, Wek’èezhii, and Akaitcho Geographic Regions, which encompass the most significantly burned areas from the 2014 fire season.  Within these regions, we examined water quality across a series of 50 catchments that varied based on within-catchment fire extent, ecoregion (Taiga Plains vs. Taiga Shield), and within-catchment characteristics such as wetland extent. This sampling scheme – which covers as significant a range of landscape variability as possible – is allowing us to tease apart the effects of wildfire from other landscape variables that cumulatively impact aquatic ecosystem health. We find that the effects of wildfire on stream water chemistry are relatively weak when measured at stream outlets, but that these effects can teased apart from other, key landscape attributes with the use of multivariate analyses and a large sample size. However, we do find transient changes in water quality immediately post-fire, and changes in pore water chemistry and hydrologic parameters within catchments affected by wildfire. Future work should examine long term fire-induced changes within catchments, and focus on determining the effect of wildfire during years that are relatively wet.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>

name: 10-25976-487w-f297
notes: During the summer of 2014, the southern Northwest Territories (NWT) experienced an unprecedented fire season, with a burn fingerprint that spread across two ecoregions (the Taiga Plains and Taiga Shield), and a landscape that is underlain by mosaic of permafrost coverage, vegetation type, and previous fire history.  Our study was conducted across the Dehcho, Wek’èezhii, and Akaitcho Geographic Regions, which encompass the most significantly burned areas from the 2014 fire season.  Within these regions, we examined water quality across a series of 50 catchments that varied based on within-catchment fire extent, ecoregion (Taiga Plains vs. Taiga Shield), and within-catchment characteristics such as wetland extent. This sampling scheme – which covers as significant a range of landscape variability as possible – is allowing us to tease apart the effects of wildfire from other landscape variables that cumulatively impact aquatic ecosystem health. We find that the effects of wildfire on stream water chemistry are relatively weak when measured at stream outlets, but that these effects can teased apart from other, key landscape attributes with the use of multivariate analyses and a large sample size. However, we do find transient changes in water quality immediately post-fire, and changes in pore water chemistry and hydrologic parameters within catchments affected by wildfire. Future work should examine long term fire-induced changes within catchments, and focus on determining the effect of wildfire during years that are relatively wet.

notes_translated.en: During the summer of 2014, the southern Northwest Territories (NWT) experienced an unprecedented fire season, with a burn fingerprint that spread across two ecoregions (the Taiga Plains and Taiga Shield), and a landscape that is underlain by mosaic of permafrost coverage, vegetation type, and previous fire history.  Our study was conducted across the Dehcho, Wek’èezhii, and Akaitcho Geographic Regions, which encompass the most significantly burned areas from the 2014 fire season.  Within these regions, we examined water quality across a series of 50 catchments that varied based on within-catchment fire extent, ecoregion (Taiga Plains vs. Taiga Shield), and within-catchment characteristics such as wetland extent. This sampling scheme – which covers as significant a range of landscape variability as possible – is allowing us to tease apart the effects of wildfire from other landscape variables that cumulatively impact aquatic ecosystem health. We find that the effects of wildfire on stream water chemistry are relatively weak when measured at stream outlets, but that these effects can teased apart from other, key landscape attributes with the use of multivariate analyses and a large sample size. However, we do find transient changes in water quality immediately post-fire, and changes in pore water chemistry and hydrologic parameters within catchments affected by wildfire. Future work should examine long term fire-induced changes within catchments, and focus on determining the effect of wildfire during years that are relatively wet.
notes_translated.fr: Au cours de l'été 2014, le sud des Territoires du Nord-Ouest (TNO) a connu une saison des feux sans précédent, avec une empreinte de brûlure qui s'est étendue à deux écorégions (les plaines de la taïga et le bouclier de la taïga) et un paysage sous-tendu par une mosaïque de couverture de pergélisol, de type de végétation et d'antécédents d'incendies. Notre étude a été menée dans les régions géographiques du Dehcho, du Wek'èezhii et de l'Akaitcho, qui englobent les zones les plus gravement brûlées pendant la saison des incendies de 2014. Dans ces régions, nous avons examiné la qualité de l'eau dans une série de 50 bassins versants qui variaient en fonction de l'étendue des feux à l'intérieur du bassin versant, de l'écorégion (plaines de la taïga contre bouclier de taïga) et de caractéristiques intra-bassins versants, telles que l'étendue des zones humides. Ce schéma d'échantillonnage, qui couvre une gamme aussi importante que possible de variabilité du paysage, nous permet de distinguer les effets des feux de forêt des autres variables du paysage qui ont un impact cumulatif sur la santé de l'écosystème aquatique. Nous constatons que les effets des feux de forêt sur la chimie de l'eau des cours d'eau sont relativement faibles lorsqu'ils sont mesurés à la sortie des cours d'eau, mais que ces effets peuvent être distingués d'autres caractéristiques clés du paysage grâce à des analyses multivariées et à un échantillon de grande taille. Cependant, nous constatons des changements transitoires dans la qualité de l'eau immédiatement après un incendie, ainsi que des changements dans la chimie de l'eau interstitielle et les paramètres hydrologiques dans les bassins versants touchés par les feux de forêt. Les travaux futurs devraient examiner les changements à long terme induits par les incendies dans les bassins versants et se concentrer sur la détermination de l'effet des feux de forêt pendant les années relativement humides.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.
